text.p: The following are the main stories from Wednesday morning's German newspapers:
- Former East German spy leader Markus Wolf disputes prosecutor's charges he coerced and kidnapped, sees himself as victim of political trial.
- Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel convinced NATO will reach agreement with Russia on NATO expansion, says Russia knows NATO expansion is coming at some point.

- German President Roman Herzog decides to turn down a 1.3 percent pay raise due him this year. He will receive 29,402 marks per year. Chancellor Helmut Kohl and Cabinet ministers also freeze pay. Kohl receives 26,468 marks per month.
- More domestic orders recorded in manufacturing industry in November compared to October.

- Kirch and Springer fighting over stakes in network SAT-1. Kirch wants to raise stake to 59 percent from 43 percent. Springer has 35 percent and protests to other shareholders planning to sell their stakes to Kirch.
- BMW sets delivery record in 1996 with 1.1 million cars deliviered.
- Unions criticise Economics Minister Guenter Rexrodt for his remarks on changing laws to make it easier for employers to fire workers.
- Furniture and textile business suffering from weak consumer demand.

- CSU considers raising consumer taxes. Ahead of three-day part conference, CSU calls for outlines of major tax reform to be in place by January 22. CSU leaders also warn coalition partners FDP against raising their profile at expense of others.
- Transfer payments for rebuilding eastern Germany have passed the 1,000 billion mark level, finance ministry says.
- DIW institute says unemployment will rise to 11 percent in 1997, GDP will grow two percent, east will slide into recession.
